div.head:
Emory College Oxford
Oct. 10th 1848
div.p: I again attempt to write a few lines in order to let you know how I am situated and how I am getting allong along at this place. First my health is tolerably good and I am now engaged in my College exercises our College has been thrown back a great deal by the loss of one of our Proffessors but his place is now filled by one of our last graduates, but not withstanding this loss she is still increasing in the number of her students and bids fare soon to outstrip any of her sothern rivals of the South both in the number of her students and the superiority of her faculty.

We have no news of interest at present-except that politics is raging at it hightest pitch and it is yet doubtful how our state will go in the Election, but as this is a subject which ought never to trouble or interest the students I therefore pay little or no attention to it and therefore know comparatively nothing about it. I received your letter sometime since and the amount which you had inclosed within but as Kentucky money does not pas here without discount I have not yet made
use of it but as there is a great many men from Kentucky and Tenesee who drive hogs and horses through this place every winter and will be glad to change Georgia money for it I will therefore have a good chance of geting rid of assoon as the wether turns a little bit colder. I ned hardly say anything to you about money affairs as you must know that I stand greatly in kned ofsome. I wish however that you would send me enough to pay up all my accounts here and let me be square once more and I will then endeavour to keep so perhaps you may think that I spend more here than I really should do I might a little less provided had the cash to pay for any thing which I may I need but as I haf to go on the credit sistem I hafto pay very high prices for all the articles which I purchase. Tuition as also required in advance and I behind in paying for my board and washing which I would like to pay up as soon as possible as I am boarding with a Widow Lady and she is greatly in debt is is needing some money very much this I suppose will suffice on this subject and I hope that you will not think me to extravigant as I try to make every edge cut.
You have never said anything about when and how soon you intended for me to come home I would like for you to tell me something about it as I begin to be anxious for that happy period to arrive when I had this place for home dont understand one to say that I dislike this place not as I like it as well as I could like any place away from home but I begin to want to see home pretty badly. Bishop Andrew from this place will attend your conference to be held in Lagrange and said perhaps that he would pay you a visit you must see the Bishop if you can make it convienient as I know that you cannot help being pleased with him boath as a man and as a preacher. Mr Agcock will return in a few weaks in company with two others your me whom he has persuaded to try our county.

You must write soon and write often for I have not received but one letter from home since Agcock, Mr. Mr Agcock left there and I had allmost given out the idea of hearing from any of you again. Give my love to all and tell Mother that she must write to oftener than she does my love to little Mary in particular as I long see her as well as the rest of ya I remain youre son.
